channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: In German Town, a School-Year Highlight That Ended in Disaster
item.description: During this time of year, tens of thousands of students just like them, all over the world, board planes for a week or two of foreign culture, likely the highlight of their school year.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING and MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Rolf Vennenbernd/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Students and teachers from the Joseph-König school in Germany were returning from a language and culture immersion program in Spain when their plane crashed on Tuesday.

item.title: No Survivors as Germanwings Airbus Carrying 150 Crashes in French Alps
item.description: The jet, en route from Barcelona to Düsseldorf, went down in the southern Alps, apparently killing all 150 people on board. Officials said its cockpit voice recorder had been found.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: A rescue helicopter over the French Alps near the crash site of the Airbus A320 on Tuesday.

item.title: Open Source: Afghan Protesters Demand Justice for Woman Killed by Mob
item.description: Protesters rallied outside Afghanistan’s high court in support of a woman beaten to death after being falsely accused of burning pages from the Quran.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Puts a Hitch in the Step of ‘Dancing Grannies’
item.description: The Chinese government has issued rules that aim to regulate the ad hoc public dancing that has become popular in recent years.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Large-scale organized dancing in a public square in Tianjin, China.

item.title: U.S. Agrees to Slow Pullout of Troops From Afghanistan
item.description: President Obama made the change at the request of President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan, who is visiting Washington.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Israel Denies Spying on Iran Nuclear Talks
item.description: Three top Israeli ministers rebutted a published report that Israel spied on closed-door talks between Iran and six world powers, including the United States.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry with Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif of Iran in Geneva in January. Tensions between the United States and Israel are high because of disagreement on an emerging nuclear deal with Tehran.

item.title: Radio and TV Martí, U.S. Broadcasters for Cuba, Face New Obstacles
item.description: The Martís are illegal on the island, and President Raúl Castro has made their shutdown a condition of normalizing relations with the United States.
item.dc:creator: LIZETTE ALVAREZ
item.media:credit: Angel Valentin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A taping at the TV Martí studio in Miami this month.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: The Curious Case of the Chinese Taxi Driver Turned Spy
item.description: The unlikely story of Mr. Duan is one of a series of reports in the Chinese news media over the last year about street-level agents recruited online by foreign countries or organizations, reflecting heightened concerns over espionage.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER
item.media:description: Chinese J-10 fighter jets lined up in Zhuhai, Guangdong Province, after their arrival for an aviation exhibition.

item.title: Lens Blog: Conflict, Courage and Healing in Gaza
item.description: Heidi Levine’s coverage of the conflict in Gaza earned her the first Anja Niedringhaus Courage in Photojournalism Award, which honors the Associated Press photographer killed while working in Afghanistan.
item.category: Anja Niedringhaus Courage in Photojournalism Award
item.dc:creator: JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: Heidi Levine photographing Palestinian fighters during a training exercise near Khan Younis, Gaza. Aug. 6, 2008.

item.title: Indian Court Strikes Down Section of Law Punishing Offensive Online Posts
item.description: The judgment by the Supreme Court was regarded as a landmark ruling on free speech in the country.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR and SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: A man with his smartphone in New Delhi. The Indian Supreme Court's judgment was regarded as a landmark ruling on free speech in the country.

item.title: Málaga, Spain's Self-Appointed New Arts Hub
item.description: The southern Spanish city of Málaga has persuaded two prestigious museums to open their first overseas offshoots: the Pompidou Center from Paris and the State Russian Museum from Saint Petersburg.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Outside the new “pop-up” Pompidou Center in Málaga, which is opening on Saturday.

item.title: ISIS Militants Stone an Iraqi Couple Accused of Adultery
item.description: The man and women were killed in Mosul, and residents said it was one of more than a dozen stonings since the militants took control.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Singapore, the Nation That Lee Kuan Yew Built, Questions Its Direction
item.description: Citizens of the sleek Asian financial hub wonder whether it has outgrown Lee Kuan Yew’s father-knows-best style of government.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE and THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: For the people of Singapore, rising living costs and soaring property prices are among the most prominent and contentious issues.

item.title: Greece Says It’ll Present E.U. With Planned Overhauls by Monday
item.description: The announcement came as Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras met supporters and leading government ministers on his first official visit to Germany.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece visited the Holocaust Memorial in Berlin on Tuesday. Mr. Tsipras has cut an unusual figure among European leaders since being elected less than two months ago.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Greece’s Unhappy Marriage
item.description: Greeks may resent their dependence upon their eurozone neighbors, but history shows that they need them.
item.dc:creator: JAMES ANGELOS

item.title: China Executes 3 Over Deadly Knife Attack at Train Station in 2014
item.description: Many Chinese had equated the attack at the Kunming station in Yunnan Province to the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks in New York and Washington.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: The train station in Kunming, China, where 31 people died in a knife attack last year. A provincial court said on Tuesday that three men were executed for carrying out the attack.

item.title: Gunmen Carry Out Deadly Attack on 3 Vehicles on Afghan Highway
item.description: The episode is the latest in a series of assaults on a major road connecting Kabul and Kandahar, and a grim reminder of the dangers of traveling across Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and FAZAL MUZHARY
item.media:description: Security officers searched cars and passengers at a checkpoint in Ghazni, Afghanistan, on Tuesday after gunmen opened fire on a bus.

item.title: David Cameron Rules Out Third Term as Prime Minister of Britain
item.description: In a BBC interview, he said he would complete his second term but would not run again after that, a stance that could undermine his authority if he wins on May 7.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain at the European Union leaders summit meeting last week in Brussels.

item.title: Episode 1: Meet Our Man in Tehran
item.description: In a new video series, Thomas Erdbrink, the Tehran bureau chief for The New York Times, interviews the people of Iran, a country that is slowly changing and where nothing is as it seems.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Iraqi Forces Map Plan Against ISIS, With Strategic Use of Militias
item.description: The hard lessons of the Tikrit offensive, which brought high casualties, have Iraqi officials thinking more cautiously about their next steps.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Shiite and Sunni fighters joined Iraqi forces against ISIS outside former President Saddam Hussein’s palace near Tikrit.
